div.head: THE EGYPTIAN GAZETTE
No. 7194] ALEXANDRIA, WEDNESDAY, MAY 1O, 1905. [EIGHT PAGES P.T. 1.
FRANCE AND JAPAN. THE NEUTRALITY QUESTION. FRENCH PRECAUTIONS.
div.p: Paris, May 9. The Japanese Minister has not lodged a formal protest, but pointed oat the facilities accorded to the Russians for concentrating and revictualling in Indo China. M. Delcassé as- sured him that France will scrupulously respect neutrality. (Reuter.)

Paris, May 9. The French resent considerably the charge that they have violated the neutrality. They insist that they have done everything possible from the moment Admiral Rodjestvensky arrived unannounced at Kamaranh. They are certainly now bestirring themselves to move on Admiral Rodjestvensky whenever he shows signs of stopping in French waters. (Reuter.)

Paris, May 9. France has given formal orders to prevent the, junction of Rodjestvensky’s and Niebo- gatoff’s squadrons in Indo-Chinese waters. Admiral de Jonquiecres confirms the depar- ture of the Russian squadron from Vanfong for an unknown destination. (Reuter.)

div.head: LONDON PRESS OPINION.
div.p: London, May 9. The newspapers admit that the situation is unsatisfactory but do not consider it critical. The "Standard” is not surprised that the Japanese are bitterly aggrieved at the assist- ance given to their enemy, but trusts that they will refrain from any. semblance of dictation. Tokio will be playing the game of St. Peters- burg by introducing into the war a new factor of au incalculable magnitude.

The "Morning Post" says that nobody in England dreams of escaping the obligations of the Japanese alliance. The maintenance of tho entente cordiale is only possible if Great Britain and France will abstain from assisting their respective allies. People in Great Britain rely on the chivalry of the French to strictly observe neutrality. (Reuter.)

div.head: THE BALTIC FLEET.
div.p: Saigon, May 9. The Russian fleet left Hon Koke southwards towards another bay, where the French men- of-war located it, Admiral Rodjestvensky stated that he is leaving immediately. (R.)

div.head: MANCHURIA. JAPANESE TACTICS.
div.p: St. Petersburg, May 9. The Russian correspondents in Manchuria concur in believing that the Japanese are moving slowly and surely under the screen of advanced posts so impenetrable that our cavalry can learn nothing. (Reuter.)

div.head: PARLIAMENT FOR RUSSIA. RUSSIAN MINISTER'S SCHEME.
div.p: St. Petersburg, May 9. The Russian Minister of the Interior has dratted a scheme, which is liable to modifica- tion, for the establishment of a form of Parlia ment with two Houses, whereof the lower will consist of 550 elected deputies, while the existing Council of the Empire will constitute the upper. (Reuter )
Moscow, May 9. The congress of delegates of the Zemstvos has passed a vote in favor of universal suffrage and the creation of two Chambers. (Havas.)

div.head: GODLESSNESS IN GERMAN ARMY. KAISER'S CHARACTERISTIC SPEECH.
div.p: Berlin, May 9. The Church paper publishes a characteristic speech made by the Emperor to the naval recruits on tLe 9th March. The Emperor Wil- liam said be feared that godlessness is pene- trating into the German Army, and that he hoped it would riot be punished some day as Russia is now being punished by Japan, which is acting as God’s scourge like Attila and Napoleon. (Reuter.)

div.head: ANTI-SEMITIC OUTBREAK.
div.p: Warsaw, May 9. An anti-Semitic outbreak baa taken place at Jitomir. It was attended by fierce fighting as the Jews were armed, having been forewarned. There are 12 killed and 50 wounded. (Reuter.)

div.head: DESTRUCTIVE TORNADO.
div.p: Kansas City, May 9. A tornado razed a track 120 feet wide throughout the whole length of the town of Marquette. There are 24 killed and 35 injured. (Reuter.)

div.head: THE CRETAN INSURRECTION.
div.p: Rome, May 9. It has been decided to send two warships to Crete. (Havas.)

div.head: HOME CRICKET.
div.p: London, May 9. Lancashire beat Leicestershire by 9 wickets. Yorkshire beat Gloucestershire by winnings and 55 runs.(Reuter)

div.p: The Brindisi Mail will be distributed at the G. P. O., Alexandria, at 9.30 p.m. to day.
Gambling Hell Raided. — The Alexandria City Police made a raid last night on a gambling hell at Gabbari.
Foot and Mouth Disease exists in Egypt The bills of health of ships leaving our ports bear an annotation to that effect.
THE BOOK CLUB-We are requested to state that in future the library will be open on Tues- days and Fridays between 4.45 and 6 p.m.
STRAY AND OWNERLESS DOGS found in the Khalifa district of Cairo during the night of Thursday and dawn of Friday, and in the Mousky during the night of Friday, will be poisoned by the police.

"TURKISH” TOBACCO — The British South Africa Company has received from Rhodesia a consignment of "Turkish” tobacco which was grown near Buluwayo this season. Fifty acres were planted with this tobacco.

THE SADAT AFFAIR.—The Mehkemeh Sharieh of Cairo will enquire into the case of the wife and daughter of Sheikh el Sadat, who fled from the sheikh’s house some weeks ago. The Court will meet on the 24th inst.

HELLENIC ASSIZES.—The opening of the Hellenic Assize Court at Alexandria will take place on the 14th-inst. M. Antonopoulo, of tho Athenian Appeal Court, will arrive .here on Saturday to preside over the Assize Court.

SUEZ CANAL.—20 vessels passed through the Canal on the 6th and 7th inst. Of these 12 were British, 5 German, 1 French, 1 Norwe gian, 1 Spanish. The receipts for the two days were frs. 635,838.58, making the total from the 1st inst. frs. 2,370,686.

Khedivial Geographical Society.—Owing to the fêtes prepared by tho committee ad hoc, the Khedivial Geographical Society has post- poned to the 19th the stance commemorative of the geographical work of Mohamed Aly, which it had prepared for the 13th inst.

Frauds on Illiterate Persons.—The man who, in bis capacity of public letter-writer, was in the habit of stealing the stamps affixed to letters, which ho posted unpaid, and who was detected by the Abbassieh post- master, has been sentenced to two months' imprisonment

Police Outrage.—A great scandal has been created at Mellawi owing to the disgraceful conduct of a police officer in that town, who attempted to commit an assault on a Coptio lady. Her screams attracted the neighbours, who succeeded in rescuing her from the clut- ches of the officer. The matter is being inves- tigated by the Ministry of the Interior.

Dismissal of Cadi.—A council of discipline was held this morning under the presidency of HE. Fuad Pasha, Minister of Justice, when the case of the Cadi of the Tahta Mehkemeh was tried. The question of falsification was not considered, but the cadi was found guilty of administrative irregularities to the prejudice of the magistracy and was dismissed from the service.

Repression of Slave Trade.—A general court martial will assemble at the Rod Barracks, Abbassieh, on Thursday under the presidency of El Miralai Mahmoud Bey Taufik, director of the Military School, when Gameh Abou Said, an Ababdeh Arab, will be tried for purchasing and attempting to resell Aisha, a Sudanese woman. El Saghkolaghasi Ahmed Effendi Bekir has been appointed prosecutor.

(Euvre des Enfants' Abandonnés.— The annual meeting of the charity sisters, presided over by Rev. Father Amaddio Amato, in the absence of the Archbishop, took place on Monday. The ladies of the committee of the Foundlings' Home and a number of patronesses were present. The report on the good work done during the past year was read and approved. Pressure on our space prevents us from dealing with this interesting document to-day.

div.head: SUDAN IRRIGATION SCHEME. THE NEW CANAL.
div.p: ( From our Correspondent ).

Khartoum, May 2. One of the most important irrigation schemes under consideration in the Sudan is the pro- posed canal across El Ghezireh, whereby the White end Blue Niles will be connected,and so form a main canal which will extend to Khar- toum. Great difficulties are likely to be en- countered in the realisation of the scheme, but when the canal is completed it will prove of the greatest utility to the lands it will traverse, and will repay all the difficulties of construc- tion.

Cattle plague has made its appearance in Kassala Province. The necessary steps have been taken for stamping out the disease and preventing it from spreading to the adjoining province of Sennar and the Blue Nile Pro- vince. Admirably equipped quarantine stations were established on the boundary of each pro- vince and the rind rpest was kept out This should serve as a lesson to the Egyptian authorities.

div.head: IMMIGRATION TO EGYPT.
div.p: The recent boom in things Egyptian, and the great publicity which this country enjoys in the English Press at the present time, appears to have given many people at home and in the colonies the opinion that it is a likely country to emigrate to. We have re- ceived some letters asking for advice on the subject, of which the following is a sample:—

"Dear Sir,—There are a lot of young men down here, who are wishing to go up to Egypt or in that direction. If you could advise mo through your colomns as to what prospects there are likely to be you will greatly oblige.—Yours faithfully, E..A. Crosbie. "Bloemfontein, Orange River Colony, April 4.”

In regard to the above, we earnestly advise these young men of the Orange Free State to refrain from starting for Egypt without having first obtained satisfactory, assurance as to the situations they will fill on arriving here. To come to Egypt on the look-out for something to “turn up” may in some cases turn out a successful venture. But for "a lot" of young men to arrive here on the off chance of finding appointments will only lead to disappointments.

div.head: THE ECLIPSE IN EGYPT.
div.p: Arrangements are being set on foot which ure of interest to Egypt by the British Astronomical Association, towards making complete and accurate observations of the solar eclipse, which is due. b about four mouths' time. At the monthly meeting of tho association Mr. A.CD. Crommelin, the presi- dent, intimated to its members that if was imperative that every class of observation should be taken. With this end b view endea- vours are being made to dispatch parties or observers to Egypt and Labrador, the object being, of course, to take full advantage of the fact that this year, for the first time for many, there will be a long totality, of eclipse visible in these and other accessible places. As the association lacks nothing b zeal, energy, and enterprise in the pursuance of both observation red research, it is certain that the arrange- ments for the sending of observers to Egypt and Labrador will be brought to a satisfactory completion.

div.head: UPPER EGYPT HOTELS COMPANY.
div.p: The site of the new hotel at Luxor, which this company has chosen, is on the right side of the Nile, at the end of Luxor village, com- manding a lovely view of the Theban moun- tains and of the river. Building operations are to be commended at once. The architectural designs have already been made, and it is expected that the hotel will be ready for the reception of visitors by October, 1906. It will contain 250 rooms and will accommodate 280 people.
The construction of a new wing to the Cataract Hotel at Assouan has already been commenced. This wing will accommodate 75 visitors.
The Grand Hotel at Assouan is also being enlarged this year and rooms for 75 tourists are to be provided.
A number of improvements are also to be made at the Savoy Hotel on Elephantine Island.

The hall at the Cataract Hotel is to be greatly enlarged so as to give ample space for the 350. visitors which the hotel will accom- modate under its new management. Already a great number of tourists have ordered apart- ments at the hotels at Assouan and Luxor for next season, as this season it was most difficult to find rooms and habitues of Upper Egypt have therefore determined to be betimes in their orders for the coming season. The financial position of the company is considered to be very satisfactory, as all its properties are bound to rise in value, and the board of di- rectors is so strong that the greatest confidence is felt in their management

div.head: RETURN OF THE MAHMAL. ARRIVAL AT SUEZ. (FROM OUR CORRESPONDENT).
div.p: Suez, Tuesday. The Mahmal arrived at Suez this morning by the Khedivial Mail liner "Rahmanieh, and last year’s Holy Carpet was landed at the docks in the forenoon.

At four o’clock this afternoon the usual pro- cession took place through the principal street of Suez, accompanied by infantry, cavalry artillery, the military band, etc., and pre sen ted a remarkable aspect. Towards evening; the Mahmal was placed in a special train which will leave for Cairo at 9 o’clock. Large numbers of Egyptian pilgrims arrive) yesterday by the Khedivial steamers "Mariout” and “Missir,” of whom the majority left in the evening by a special pilgrim train, thus bring- ing to an end the pilgrim season.

div.head: MOHAMED ALY CENTENARY.
div.p: Prince Said Halim and other members of the Khedivial Family have decided to commemorate the centenary of the founder of the dynasty by opening a subscription for sending ten young Egyptians to complete their education in the Universities of Europe. The first list of sub scriptions amounts to £5,000, and includes the following:—Prince Said Pasha Halim, £1,000 Prince Abbas Pasha Halim, £1,000 ; Prince Haidar Bey Fazel, £500 ; Idris Bey Ragheb Hassan Pasha Wassif, Youssef Pasha Talaat Omar Bey Soultan, and Medhat Bey Yaghen £500 each.

div.head: SANITARY DEPARTMENT.
div.p: Dr. Charles Todd, resident bacteriologist at the Serum Institute tor cattle plague Abbassieh, has been appointed bacteriologist of the 2nd class to the Sanitary Department at a salary of L.E. 50 per month. Dr. Werner von Rathen has been appoint- ed bacteriologist of the 3rd class— at a salary of L.E. 40 per month.

div.head: NEW ITALIAN CONSUL.
div.p: (From our Correspondent). Port Said, Tuesday. Yesterday morning, Comte Mancinelli Scotto who, with his wife and child, arrived from Alexandria during the night and took up residence in the Eastern Exchange Hotel, took over his new post at the Italian Consulate This gentleman relieves Comte Cassis Domi- nioni, who left to take up an appointment in the diplomatic service in Innsbruck, Austria Since Comte Dominioni left, over seven months ago, Comte Senni has been in charge of Italian interests in this town. The new Consul brings with him an excellent record, he having served his department for many years, the last few in America and Europe. He speaks English and French most fluently.

div.head: THE NEW SUEZ CANAL DIRECTOR
div.p: Referring to the feet that Mr. Hughes, of I. and J. Harrison and Co., of Liverpool, ha been lately offered and has accepted a seat on the board of directors of the Suez Canal Com- pony, "Fairplay," in a recent article, remark that it is a little strange that this gentleman is a prominent member of the only shipping association in England which has no con- nection with the Chamber of Shipping. The Chamber has for a length of time been at the root of all the agitation for a reduction in rates on ships going through the Canal and fo the appointment of a representative “tramp” owner on the board. In Mr. Hughes, the Bri- tish ship-owner, it is firmly believed, will be moat ably represented. He is a gentleman whose connection with one of the most go- ahead firms in England is well-known, and if reductions and drastic alterations are in any way possible, tip interest of the British ship owner, both tramp and liner, may most safely be left in his hands.

div.head: THE PIGMIES AT CAIRO. SIR H. JOHNSTONE'S OPINION.
div.p: In regard to the permission, sanctioned by Lord Cromer and the Foreign Office, for the pigmies to leave Cairo for England, as announc- ed in our issue of yesterday, it is worth noting that the humanitarian protest that has been raised against Colonel Harrison's enterprise of bringng specimens of the pigmy or Akka race from the African interior is met by the more than sufficient reason that the little people have desired for some years past for a few of their people to make the trip. And the views put forward b the follow- ing conversation, coming as they do from an independent and eminent authority, should correct a deal of illusion that has been generally entertained concerning the project and its aims.

Sir Harry Johnstone, interviewed by a Pressman, illustrated several of his points by drawing attention to a couple of water-colour sketches from his own accomplished pencil. One represented a man and woman of the races in question; the other a native of a neighbouring tribe of higher caste and origin. The pigmies—both typical—reveal a copper- coloured tinge of skin, an obesity of build possibly due to overmuch squatting, and certain negroid qualities of feature — the swollen lips, spatulate nose, receding forehead and half-frizzy hair. The type in the sketch alongside might rank as an aristocrat not only in this region but anywhere else, by virtue of a certain nobility and command in his facial expression, and a featuring not unlike the faces that come to light in the mummies of his ancestral Egypt But it is with the baser race that we are at present occupied, and Sir Harry Johnston had some- thing to say at the outset regarding his own attitude in the matter.
THE HUMANITARIAN VIEW.

"I never resented interest,” he said, "on the part of persons in England whose concern is for races unable to protect themselves, as no doubt Exeter Hall and all that it implies have again and again kept the British nation in the right track as regards its treatment of defenceless people. At the same time, the parallels advanced by those who wrote to protest against Colonel Harrison’s bringing these people to England were not altogether correct. My own action was quoted in having, first, stopped a German who kidnapped a large number of pigmies in the Congo forest for the purpose of exhibiting them in Paris and, secondly, for having sent back pigmies to their homes who had come to us at their own wish in order that they should be taken to England to greet England’s new King.

"With regard to the first case, the German in question was refused permission by the Belgian authorities in the Congo Free State to recruit pigmies for conveyance to the Paris Exhibition. In spite of this prohibition he had entered the forest where these pigmies lived, had lured them to his camp by small presents of trade goods, and had then suddenly kid- napped a number of them whom be placed in bonds and conveyed out of the forest by devious tracks until be reached British territory."
THEIR DESIRE TO SEE ENGLAND.
“Did they show their gratitude?” we inquir- ed.

" Certainly. One result of my conveying these pigmies back to their own homes was a much-increased interest in the white people, especially those of the race that ruled in Uganda; and it is a fact that a few-months afterwards several pigmies came to me at Entebbe and asked to be taken to England to see the new King. At that time, however, I was in indifferent health, and did not feel able to take upon myself the responsibility of conveying these little people to England, looking after their health and comfort, and then taking mea- sures to have them safely transported bock to their homes.

"In Colonel Harrison's case I happen to know that he has omitted no formality, and that the pigmies really wish to accompany him to see what England is like. About four years ago the wife of a German official in German East Africa took two pigmy women back with her to Berlin, who had previously been in her service in Africa, and proved very deft maid-servants. They stayed about a year in Berlin, and on their return to the interior of East Africa appeared to have brought back very favourable accounts of the way in which pigmies were treated by white men.”
CONSIDERATIONS OF PIGMY HEALTH.
“There is no reason, of course,” we remark- ed, “why the present visit should not have the same happy results.”

"No," was the reply, "but I do not think that it would be right that these pigmies who have come with Colonel Harrison should be made a show of. Let them spend two or three months in our country and then return to their own land. If they are able to take back favor- able impressions, and, above all, if their health has not suffered, then it may be time to con- aider an invitation for a large number to come amongst us, as the Somalis have done, and exhibit their curious and interesting dances and songs."

On this same question of health—and, after all, it is the most important aspect of the question—Sir Harry Johnston forbore to say anything for fear of being betrayed into pro- phecy. He remarked, however, that the pigmies are hardy enough while leading a forest life, and it is only when they emerge into glaring sunshine like that of Egypt that they exhibit any physical weakness or discomfort. The natural retort to this is that England is not likely to disturb their physical balance by sunshine in excess ; and after this view on onr part. Sir Harry passed on to discuss their remarkable natural powers and quickness of a apprehension. He recounted how is his first dealings with them he was at a loss for fear mouths, simply because of their ignorance of any language he was acquainted with; but when they set themselves to master the rudi- ments of Arabic their progress was amazing.

div.head: DIPLOMATIC AND MISSIONARY ASPECTS.
div.p: “If only these pigmies are properly treated," Sir Harry continued, "and sent back with good reports, it may have the most potent effect b bringing this race into touch with so much civilisation as would benefit them. In this respect we cannot do better than persuade the Church Missionary Society of Uganda to establish a branch of their mission b pigmy- land, to do for the pigmies just what it has done for the Baganda—that is to say, not to attempt to turn them into coloured imitations of white people, dressed in utterly unsuitable white men's clothes; but to teach them to lead healthy, happy, and useful lives.

"The work of the missionaries in Uganda has been so absolutely successful that it ought to serve as a model for all mission work in other parts of Africa. This opinion is echoed, I may say, by every recent administrator of those parts of Africa. In a way, it reminds me of the work of the French in Tunis. The French have everywhere introduced law, order, safety, comfort, cheapness, and celerity of transport into Tunis without disturbing one particle of the picturesqueness of the country. In the same way, missionary work in the Uganda Protectorate has relieved the people from a most oppressive and bloodthirsty from of religion, and from an immorality which was rapidly leading to depopulation. It has done more, for it has introduoed just that amount of the white man’s civilisation which is suited to the native of equatorial Africa; and yet, marvellous to relate, there is no cant and no hypocrisy. I should strongly recommend, as the first missionary to the pigmies, such a man as Mr. A. B. Fisher or Mr. Maddox, both of whom have done such excellent work b approaching and rendering friendly hitherto recalcitrant tribes on the western borderland of Uganda."
